awd_titl_txt: CIVIC-PG Track B: Co-Design of Integrated Energy and Mobility Hubs for Service and Resiliency
awd_abstract_narration:
This Civic Innovation Challenge (CIVIC) Project aims to develop decision support tools and designs that support community-led collaborative initiatives to improve energy and transportation services. Recent natural disasters have underscored the vulnerability of the nation’s electric power grids and transportation networks, as well as the catastrophic social, economic, and environmental consequences that follow their failure. In response to this reality, this project’s vision is that communities, particularly those most vulnerable, must have access to tools that can empower them to collaboratively establish resilient, decentralized, clean power generating systems that meet their basic electricity needs and that can drive their transition to emerging transportation modes and services. To this end, the project will advance research on the design and implementation of integrated energy and mobility micro hubs that can provide support, even in the aftermath of natural disasters, to the critical services required to ensure the health, prosperity, and welfare of communities. In addition, the research project will explore the development of education and training initiatives to prepare the workforce needed to install and maintain the micro hubs. 

Specific objectives of the project include: i) create analytical frameworks and tools that can aid in the co-design of low-cost, clean energy micro hubs (i.e., small scale power generation systems) that support more resilient electric power services, ii) use the frameworks to co-design, build and install prototypes of the energy micro hubs in communities in Puerto Rico, iii) develop strategies that leverage the power generated in the energy hubs to support new shared mobility options, iv) and develop models for the implementation of workforce development-training programs that help communities to implement and drive innovations that address their needs. Lastly, using the experiences in Puerto Rico with the service hubs, the project aims to identify lessons that can help other communities in the continental US bridge energy and mobility gaps. The planning grant objectives are to: i) identify energy, transportation, and workforce service gaps in rural communities located in Puerto Rico, ii) explore to what extent collaborative energy and transportation hubs can address the needs of the communities, and iii) explore and document models and data that can be leveraged to advance the design of the service hubs, while also advancing new workforce development and business models associated with the multi-use micro-hubs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to plan a pilot project for the design, implementation, and evaluation of an integrated energy-mobility micro-hub that can help bridge gaps between the needs of rural communities and essential services, and increase resilience to natural disasters. Through workshops, community visits, and a survey, the research team collaborated with local community groups, non-governmental organizations, industry partners, and representatives from government agencies to gather data on the energy and mobility needs of rural communities in Puerto Rico (PR), particularly given the impacts on the island of Hurricane Maria in 2017 and Hurricane Fiona in 2022. The team also examined the features that an energy-mobility micro-hub requires to help address rural community needs in the PR context. This collaborative work produced a pilot project proposal for an energy-mobility hub for the community of Corcovada, PR, that integrates a solar-based energy system and an on-demand transit service. 

The results of the data analysis revealed that rural communities in PR are particularly affected by the island’s unreliable electric grid service. For example, due to Hurricane Fiona, 22% of survey participants in urban and suburban areas indicated that they lost power for 15 days or longer, while this number was 47.5% in the case of rural participants. Using survey data, the team also developed models to explore people’s interest in the energy-mobility micro-hub concept. The models suggest that demand for the micro-hubs depends primarily on the travel time to and service wait time at the hub. Additionally, the research team found that rural community partners were primarily concerned about the lack of mobility alternatives for the elderly. This motivated an analysis of the municipal transit services in PR, which found that the transit systems were less productive (in terms of passenger trips per hour) and more expensive (in terms of operating expenses per trip) than similar services in the U.S., particularly in the case of paratransit services. For instance, municipal paratransit services in PR are 55% less productive and 35% more expensive than similar small-scale services in the U.S. Given the need to offer and evaluate the performance of new mobility alternatives in PR, the application NREL OpenPATH was deployed to gather data on travel patterns in the western part of the island where the main civic partners of the project are located.

This project provided opportunities for researchers, industry partners, and government officials to collaborate with underrepresented, low-income communities in rural PR on issues that affect their daily lives. It also provided research and educational opportunities to students from underrepresented groups that are interested in energy and transportation issues. Nine students conducted research on the design of micro-hubs, transit performance evaluation, and optimization approaches to the location of resilience hubs. The collaborative work resulted in preliminary designs for solar-powered micro-hubs that can be used to charge light electric vehicles, such as e-bikes and e-scooters.
